text: Lin Yun-Ju () is a table tennis player from Taiwan. He is a left-handed player who plays with the shakehand grip and is sponsored by Butterfly. He is ranked world number 7 as of August 2020. Lin was born in Yuanshan, Yilan County, Taiwan. Lin started competing in the International Table Tennis Federation (ITTF) senior circuit. He has won two major tournaments in a row, first the T2 Diamond Malaysia 2019 in July 2019, followed in August by his first ITTF World Tour title, the Czech Open 2019 at the age of only 18. In these tournaments, he had beaten some of the top players, including Ma Long, Fan Zhendong, Dimitrij Ovtcharov and Timo Boll. He graduated from Taipei Municipal Nei-Hu Vocational High School and is currently studying at Fu Jen Catholic University.賀!!本校體碩二鄭怡靜、體大一林昀儒同學桌球混雙取得2020東京奧運門票 - 輔仁大學全球資訊網 ==Achievements== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:small;" data-ve- attributes="{"style":"text-align:center; font-size:small;"}" |+ Majors (Olympic Games, World Championships, World Cup) ! rowspan="2" width="80" |Year ! rowspan="2" width="180" |Event ! rowspan="2" width="80" href="Image:Med 2.png" |Location ! colspan="3" width="240" resource="Image:Med 2.png" height |Type |- ! width="80" |Singles ! width="80" href="Image:Med 1.png" |Doubles ! width="80" resource="Image:Med 1.png" height |Team |- ! rowspan="1" |2019 |Table Tennis World Cup (Men's Singles) | href="Image:Med 2.png" |Chengdu, China | bgcolor="Silver" |The second runner-up | href="Image:Med 1.png" |－ | resource="Image:Med 1.png" height width |－ |- |- |} ==References== ==External links== * Lin Yun-Ju at the International Table Tennis Federation Category:Taiwanese male table tennis players Category:Living people Category:Table tennis players at the 2018 Asian Games Category:Asian Games medalists in table tennis Category:Asian Games bronze medalists for Chinese Taipei Category:Medalists at the 2018 Asian Games Category:2001 births Category:Fu Jen Catholic University alumni Category:Table tennis players at the 2018 Summer Youth Olympics
